Authors:
Ekarin Chulikorn, Ei Kawahara, Yoshiko Nakaya, Taiga
Kasuya, Yuki Mizutani, Takeru Oyama, Chika Tsuchida, Toshiko Iwasaki,
Toshiyuki Ogasawara
Title:
Internal transcribed spacer and β-tubulin gene DNA barcoding
for Aspergillus welwitschiae forming a fungus ball with calcium oxalate
in the maxillary sinus
Keywords:
ITS, β-tubulin, Aspergillus niger, Aspergillus
welwitschiae, calcium oxalate
Abstract:
Background: Calcium oxalate crystals are pathognomonic
byproducts in mycosis chiefly caused by Aspergillus niger in traditional
taxonomy. However, Aspergillus section Nigri, including Aspergillus
niger sensu stricto, within which morphological differentiation is
usually difficult, has become one of the largest groups in the genus
Aspergillus due to recent advances in molecular phylogeny. A DNA
barcoding system using the nuclear ribosomal internal transcribed spacer
(ITS) and β-tubulin gene, which has been widely used in the
identification of Aspergillus section Nigri, could be a useful tool for
identification. Results: A fungus ball was resected from a patients
maxillary sinus. Imprinting cytology of the surface showed numerous
calcium oxalate crystals, suggesting A. niger infection, and careful
examination revealed unorganized, blackened microconidia and black rings
suggesting vesicles. Formalin-fixed and paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tissue
sections showed distinct macroconidial structures, indicating
Aspergillus section Nigri. To identify the species, nested PCR using
FFPE tissue sections was performed, and further TA cloning followed by
sequencing revealed the sequences of A. welwitschiae. Conclusion: ITS
and β-tubulin gene sequences of Aspergillus DNA in FFPE sections are
useful to identify the species of Aspergillus section Nigri. Molecular
testing of a pathological or cytological specimen in addition to
phenotypical observation is required to correctly identify species.
